clinical_study.brief_title: Video Assisted Ablation of Pilonidal Sinus
clinical_study.official_title: Video Assisted Ablation of Pilonidal Sinus. Evaluation of Safety and Efficacy of a New Minimally Invasive Technique

brief_summary.textblock: The investigators supposed that the complete video assisted ablation of pilonidal sinus (VAAPS) could be an effective minimally invasive treatment of pilonidal sinus. This new minimally invasive treatment allows the identification of the sinus cavity with its lateral tracks, the destruction and the removal of all infected tissue and the removing of any hair.

clinical_study.study_design: Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Treatment

primary_outcome.description: Wound infection was defined as redness and/or oedema of the skin and/or discharge

secondary_outcome.description: Recurrence can be divided into two groups: early and late. Early recurrence is usually due to failure to identify one or more sinuses. Late recurrence is usually due to secondary infection caused by residual hair or debris that was not removed at operation, inadequate wound care or insufficient attention to depilation

other_outcome.measure: Time to sitting on toilet without pain

other_outcome.description: Satisfaction Scores on the Visual Analog Scale
Aesthetic appearance on a 3 points scale of good fair and bad
Pain Scores on the Visual Analog Scale

arm_group.description: All consecutive patients with diagnosis of chronic sacrococcygeal pilonidal sinus will be screened for the enrollment in our study.

intervention.intervention_name: Video Assisted Ablation of Pilonidal Sinus

Inclusion Criteria:

Exclusion Criteria:
